challenges. HYDRO utilizes an online simulator to complement the limited amount
of offline datasets in the non-trivial context of robust RL. By measuring and
minimizing performance gaps between the simulator and the worst-case models in
the uncertainty set, HYDRO employs novel uncertainty filtering and prioritized
sampling to select the most relevant and reliable simulator samples. Our
extensive experiments demonstrate HYDRO's superior performance over existing
methods across various tasks, underscoring its potential to improve sample
efficiency in offline robust RL.

AI.tldr: The paper presents HYDRO, a Hybrid Cross-Domain Robust RL framework that combines offline datasets with an online simulator to improve sample efficiency in offline robust RL.
AI.motivation: Existing offline robust RL algorithms require extensive offline data which can be costly and time-consuming to gather. Using simulators is faster and cheaper but suffers from dynamics mismatch.
AI.method: HYDRO uses an online simulator to complement limited offline datasets in the context of robust RL. It measures and minimizes performance gaps between the simulator and worst-case models via uncertainty filtering and prioritized sampling.
AI.result: Experiments show HYDRO outperforms existing methods across various tasks, highlighting its potential to enhance sample efficiency in offline robust RL.
AI.conclusion: HYDRO is a promising approach to improve sample efficiency in offline robust RL by integrating offline data with an online simulator.

title: Training Language Models to Generate Quality Code with Program Analysis Feedback
summary:
Code generation with large language models (LLMs), often termed vibe coding,
is increasingly adopted in production but fails to ensure code quality,
particularly in security (e.g., SQL injection vulnerabilities) and
maintainability (e.g., missing type annotations). Existing methods, such as
supervised fine-tuning and rule-based post-processing, rely on labor-intensive
annotations or brittle heuristics, limiting their scalability and
effectiveness. We propose REAL, a reinforcement learning framework that
incentivizes LLMs to generate production-quality code using program
analysis-guided feedback. Specifically, REAL integrates two automated signals:
(1) program analysis detecting security or maintainability defects and (2) unit
tests ensuring functional correctness. Unlike prior work, our framework is
prompt-agnostic and reference-free, enabling scalable supervision without
manual intervention. Experiments across multiple datasets and model scales
demonstrate that REAL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in simultaneous
assessments of functionality and code quality. Our work bridges the gap between
rapid prototyping and production-ready code, enabling LLMs to deliver both
speed and quality.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces REAL, a reinforcement learning framework that encourages LLMs to generate high-quality code by using program analysis and unit test feedback. It operates without prompts or references, improving scalability and reducing manual intervention.
AI.motivation: Code generation with large language models (LLMs) has been increasingly adopted but fails to ensure quality in security and maintainability. Current methods for improvement are labor-intensive or not robust enough.
AI.method: REAL integrates automated signals from program analysis for detecting defects and unit tests for ensuring correctness. It uses reinforcement learning to incentivize LLMs to produce production-quality code without needing specific prompts or reference codes.
AI.result: Experiments show that REAL surpasses state-of-the-art methods in functionality and code quality assessments across multiple datasets and model scales.
AI.conclusion: REAL bridges the gap between rapid prototyping and production-ready code, allowing LLMs to efficiently deliver both speed and quality.

title: QLIP: A Dynamic Quadtree Vision Prior Enhances MLLM Performance Without Retraining
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) encode images into visual tokens,
aligning visual and textual signals within a shared latent space to facilitate
crossmodal representation learning. The CLIP model is a widely adopted
foundational vision language model whose vision encoder has played a critical
role in the development of MLLMs such as LLaVA. However, the CLIP vision
encoder suffers from notable limitations including being constrained to only
handling fixed input resolutions and a failure to produce separated embeddings
for dissimilar images. Replacing the vision encoder of an existing model
typically incurs substantial computational costs because such a change often
necessitates retraining the entire model pipeline.
  In this work, we identify two factors which underlie the limitations of the
CLIP vision encoder: mesoscopic bias and interpolation bias. To address these
issues, we propose QLIP, a drop-in replacement for CLIP that can be seamlessly
integrated with existing MLLMs with only a few lines of code and can enhance
both coarse-grained and fine-grained visual understanding, without re-training.
QLIP is designed around an image quadtree which replaces the standard uniform
grid patches with a novel content aware patchification. Our experimental
results demonstrate that QLIP improves the general visual question answering
accuracy of the LLaVA v1.5 model series across various model sizes--without
requiring retraining or fine-tuning of the full MLLM. Notably, QLIP boosts
detailed understanding performance on the challenging $V^{\ast}$ benchmark by
up to 13.6 percent.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces QLIP, an improved replacement for the CLIP vision encoder that enhances coarse and fine-grained visual understanding in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) like LLaVA without necessitating retraining.
AI.motivation: CLIP vision encoder has limitations such as being constrained to fixed input resolutions and failing to produce separated embeddings for dissimilar images. Replacing it typically incurs substantial computational costs due to the need for retraining the entire model pipeline.
AI.method: QLIP is proposed as a drop-in replacement for CLIP. It uses an image quadtree for content-aware patchification, addressing mesoscopic bias and interpolation bias present in CLIP. This allows seamless integration with existing MLLMs with minimal code changes.
AI.result: Experiments show that QLIP improves general visual question answering accuracy across different sizes of the LLaVA v1.5 model series without retraining or fine-tuning. It also boosts detailed understanding performance on the challenging $V^{\ast}$ benchmark by up to 13.6%.
AI.conclusion: QLIP can enhance visual understanding in MLLMs without the need for retraining, providing a more efficient alternative to the CLIP vision encoder.

title: Self-orthogonalizing attractor neural networks emerging from the free energy principle
comment:
22 pages main text, 5 pages appendix, 6 figures; interactive
  manuscript available at: https://pni-lab.github.io/fep-attractor-network
  Associated GitHub repository:
  https://github.com/pni-lab/fep-attractor-network
summary:
Attractor dynamics are a hallmark of many complex systems, including the
brain. Understanding how such self-organizing dynamics emerge from first
principles is crucial for advancing our understanding of neuronal computations
and the design of artificial intelligence systems. Here we formalize how
attractor networks emerge from the free energy principle applied to a universal
partitioning of random dynamical systems. Our approach obviates the need for
explicitly imposed learning and inference rules and identifies emergent, but
efficient and biologically plausible inference and learning dynamics for such
self-organizing systems. These result in a collective, multi-level Bayesian
active inference process. Attractors on the free energy landscape encode prior
beliefs; inference integrates sensory data into posterior beliefs; and learning
fine-tunes couplings to minimize long-term surprise. Analytically and via
simulations, we establish that the proposed networks favor approximately
orthogonalized attractor representations, a consequence of simultaneously
optimizing predictive accuracy and model complexity. These attractors
efficiently span the input subspace, enhancing generalization and the mutual
information between hidden causes and observable effects. Furthermore, while
random data presentation leads to symmetric and sparse couplings, sequential
data fosters asymmetric couplings and non-equilibrium steady-state dynamics,
offering a natural extension to conventional Boltzmann Machines. Our findings
offer a unifying theory of self-organizing attractor networks, providing novel
insights for AI and neuroscience.

AI.tldr: This paper uses the free energy principle to formalize attractor networks in random dynamical systems, leading to a multi-level Bayesian active inference process that enhances generalization and mutual information. It provides insights for AI and neuroscience.
AI.motivation: To understand how self-organizing dynamics emerge in complex systems like the brain, which is crucial for neuronal computations and artificial intelligence.
AI.method: The authors apply the free energy principle to a universal partitioning of random dynamical systems to formalize attractor networks. This approach eliminates the need for explicitly imposed learning and inference rules.
AI.result: The proposed networks favor orthogonalized attractor representations, enhancing generalization and mutual information. Sequential data fosters asymmetric couplings and non-equilibrium steady-state dynamics.
AI.conclusion: The findings present a unifying theory of self-organizing attractor networks, offering novel insights for both AI and neuroscience.

title: EmergentTTS-Eval: Evaluating TTS Models on Complex Prosodic, Expressiveness, and Linguistic Challenges Using Model-as-a-Judge
summary:
Text-to-Speech (TTS) benchmarks often fail to capture how well models handle
nuanced and semantically complex text. Building on $\textit{EmergentTTS}$, we
introduce $\textit{EmergentTTS-Eval}$, a comprehensive benchmark covering six
challenging TTS scenarios: emotions, paralinguistics, foreign words, syntactic
complexity, complex pronunciation (e.g. URLs, formulas), and questions.
Crucially, our framework automates both test-case generation and evaluation,
making the benchmark easily extensible. Starting from a small set of
human-written seed prompts, we iteratively extend them using LLMs to target
specific structural, phonetic and prosodic challenges, resulting in 1,645
diverse test cases. Moreover, we employ a model-as-a-judge approach, using a
Large Audio Language Model (LALM) to assess the speech across multiple
dimensions such as expressed emotion, prosodic, intonational, and pronunciation
accuracy. We evaluate state-of-the-art open-source and proprietary TTS systems,
such as 11Labs, Deepgram, and OpenAI's 4o-mini-TTS, on EmergentTTS-Eval,
demonstrating its ability to reveal fine-grained performance differences.
Results show that the model-as-a-judge approach offers robust TTS assessment
and a high correlation with human preferences. We open source the evaluation
$\href{https://github.com/boson-ai/EmergentTTS-Eval-public}{code}$ and the
$\href{https://huggingface.co/datasets/bosonai/EmergentTTS-Eval}{dataset}$.

AI.tldr: 提出EmergentTTS-Eval，一个涵盖六种复杂TTS场景的基准测试框架，通过自动化生成测试用例和模型评估方法，揭示不同TTS系统的细微性能差异，并开源相关代码和数据集。
AI.motivation: 现有的TTS基准测试常无法充分衡量模型对复杂语义文本的处理能力。
AI.method: 基于EmergentTTS构建EmergentTTS-Eval，包含六个挑战性场景；利用LLMs生成1,645个多样化测试用例；采用大型音频语言模型（LALM）作为评估工具。
AI.result: 该框架能有效揭示TTS系统间的细微性能差异，模型评估法与人类偏好高度相关。
AI.conclusion: EmergentTTS-Eval为TTS系统的全面评估提供了有力工具，并促进了相关研究的开放与合作。

title: Pre-Training Curriculum for Multi-Token Prediction in Language Models
summary:
Multi-token prediction (MTP) is a recently proposed pre-training objective
for language models. Rather than predicting only the next token (NTP), MTP
predicts the next $k$ tokens at each prediction step, using multiple prediction
heads. MTP has shown promise in improving downstream performance, inference
speed, and training efficiency, particularly for large models. However, prior
work has shown that smaller language models (SLMs) struggle with the MTP
objective. To address this, we propose a curriculum learning strategy for MTP
training, exploring two variants: a forward curriculum, which gradually
increases the complexity of the pre-training objective from NTP to MTP, and a
reverse curriculum, which does the opposite. Our experiments show that the
forward curriculum enables SLMs to better leverage the MTP objective during
pre-training, improving downstream NTP performance and generative output
quality, while retaining the benefits of self-speculative decoding. The reverse
curriculum achieves stronger NTP performance and output quality, but fails to
provide any self-speculative decoding benefits.

AI.tldr: Multi-token prediction (MTP) is a new pre-training objective for language models which predicts the next k tokens at each step. While it improves performance and efficiency, smaller language models struggle with MTP. This paper proposes two curriculum learning strategies: forward and reverse curricula. The forward curriculum helps small models leverage MTP, improving downstream NTP performance and generative quality while retaining self-speculative decoding benefits. The reverse curriculum achieves better NTP performance but lacks decoding benefits.
AI.motivation: The motivation of this paper is to address the challenge that smaller language models face when using the Multi-token prediction (MTP) pre-training objective. By proposing curriculum learning strategies, the aim is to help these smaller models benefit from MTP in terms of improved performance and efficiency.
AI.method: The authors explore two variants of curriculum learning strategies for MTP training: forward curriculum and reverse curriculum. The forward curriculum gradually increases the complexity of the pre-training objective from NTP to MTP, whereas the reverse curriculum does the opposite.
AI.result: The forward curriculum enables smaller language models to better utilize the MTP objective during pre-training, leading to improvements in downstream NTP performance and generative output quality while retaining the advantages of self-speculative decoding. On the other hand, the reverse curriculum results in stronger NTP performance and output quality but does not provide any self-speculative decoding benefits.
AI.conclusion: Curriculum learning strategies, particularly the forward curriculum, can significantly aid smaller language models in leveraging the MTP pre-training objective. This leads to enhancements in both performance and generative quality while preserving the benefits of self-speculative decoding.

title: Scalable Complexity Control Facilitates Reasoning Ability of LLMs
summary:
The reasoning ability of large language models (LLMs) has been rapidly
advancing in recent years, attracting interest in more fundamental approaches
that can reliably enhance their generalizability. This work demonstrates that
model complexity control, conveniently implementable by adjusting the
initialization rate and weight decay coefficient, improves the scaling law of
LLMs consistently over varying model sizes and data sizes. This gain is further
illustrated by comparing the benchmark performance of 2.4B models pretrained on
1T tokens with different complexity hyperparameters. Instead of fixing the
initialization std, we found that a constant initialization rate (the exponent
of std) enables the scaling law to descend faster in both model and data sizes.
These results indicate that complexity control is a promising direction for the
continual advancement of LLMs.

AI.tldr: 大型语言模型（LLMs）的推理能力近年来迅速提升，本研究通过调整初始化速率和权重衰减系数来控制模型复杂度，从而改进不同模型规模和数据规模下的扩展规律。研究表明，在1T token上预训练的2.4B模型中，使用恒定初始化速率（标准差的指数）而非固定初始化标准差，可以使扩展规律在模型规模和数据规模上更快下降。这表明复杂度控制是LLMs持续进步的一个有希望的方向。
AI.motivation: 尽管大型语言模型（LLMs）的推理能力正在迅速发展，但需要一种更基本的方法来可靠地增强其泛化能力。
AI.method: 通过调整初始化速率和权重衰减系数进行模型复杂度控制，并比较不同复杂度超参数下预训练模型的基准性能，探索恒定初始化速率对扩展规律的影响。
AI.result: 发现恒定初始化速率使扩展规律在模型规模和数据规模上更快下降，相较于固定初始化标准差有更好的效果。
AI.conclusion: 复杂度控制是一个有望持续提升LLMs性能的研究方向。

title: FAMA: The First Large-Scale Open-Science Speech Foundation Model for English and Italian
summary:
The development of speech foundation models (SFMs) like Whisper and
SeamlessM4T has significantly advanced the field of speech processing. However,
their closed nature--with inaccessible training data and code--poses major
reproducibility and fair evaluation challenges. While other domains have made
substantial progress toward open science by developing fully transparent models
trained on open-source (OS) code and data, similar efforts in speech remain
limited. To fill this gap, we introduce FAMA, the first family of open science
SFMs for English and Italian, trained on 150k+ hours of OS speech data.
Moreover, we present a new dataset containing 16k hours of cleaned and
pseudo-labeled speech for both languages. Results show that FAMA achieves
competitive performance compared to existing SFMs while being up to 8 times
faster. All artifacts, including code, datasets, and models, are released under
OS-compliant licenses, promoting openness in speech technology research.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces FAMA, the first family of open science speech foundation models for English and Italian, which are trained on 150k+ hours of open-source speech data. Along with this, a new dataset with 16k hours of cleaned and pseudo-labeled speech is presented. FAMA shows competitive performance compared to existing models while being significantly faster.
AI.motivation: To address the reproducibility and fair evaluation challenges posed by the closed nature of current speech foundation models (SFMs), such as inaccessible training data and code. The authors aim to promote openness in speech technology research by developing fully transparent models trained on open-source code and data.
AI.method: The authors introduce FAMA, the first family of open science SFMs for English and Italian, trained on over 150,000 hours of open-source speech data. They also present a new dataset containing 16,000 hours of cleaned and pseudo-labeled speech for both languages.
AI.result: FAMA achieves competitive performance compared to existing SFMs while being up to 8 times faster.
AI.conclusion: All artifacts, including code, datasets, and models, are released under open-source-compliant licenses, promoting openness in speech technology research.

title: Hyperbolic-PDE GNN: Spectral Graph Neural Networks in the Perspective of A System of Hyperbolic Partial Differential Equations
summary:
Graph neural networks (GNNs) leverage message passing mechanisms to learn the
topological features of graph data. Traditional GNNs learns node features in a
spatial domain unrelated to the topology, which can hardly ensure topological
features. In this paper, we formulates message passing as a system of
hyperbolic partial differential equations (hyperbolic PDEs), constituting a
dynamical system that explicitly maps node representations into a particular
solution space. This solution space is spanned by a set of eigenvectors
describing the topological structure of graphs. Within this system, for any
moment in time, a node features can be decomposed into a superposition of the
basis of eigenvectors. This not only enhances the interpretability of message
passing but also enables the explicit extraction of fundamental characteristics
about the topological structure. Furthermore, by solving this system of
hyperbolic partial differential equations, we establish a connection with
spectral graph neural networks (spectral GNNs), serving as a message passing
enhancement paradigm for spectral GNNs.We further introduce polynomials to
approximate arbitrary filter functions. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
the paradigm of hyperbolic PDEs not only exhibits strong flexibility but also
significantly enhances the performance of various spectral GNNs across diverse
graph tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a novel approach to enhance spectral graph neural networks using hyperbolic partial differential equations (PDEs) for message passing, improving interpretability and performance.
AI.motivation: Traditional GNNs struggle with ensuring topological features due to their reliance on spatial domain learning. The authors aim to address this by formulating message passing in terms of hyperbolic PDEs, which allows explicit mapping of node representations into a solution space that captures the topological structure of graphs.
AI.method: Message passing is formulated as a system of hyperbolic PDEs, creating a dynamical system that maps node representations into a solution space defined by eigenvectors describing the graph's topology. Node features are decomposed into superpositions of these eigenvectors. Polynomials are introduced to approximate arbitrary filter functions, connecting the proposed method with spectral GNNs.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that the use of hyperbolic PDEs in message passing not only offers strong flexibility but also significantly boosts the performance of various spectral GNNs across different graph tasks.
AI.conclusion: The formulation of message passing using hyperbolic PDEs enhances both the interpretability and effectiveness of spectral GNNs. This method provides a powerful enhancement paradigm for spectral GNNs.

title: A comprehensive analysis of PINNs: Variants, Applications, and Challenges
summary:
Physics Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) have been emerging as a powerful
computational tool for solving differential equations. However, the
applicability of these models is still in its initial stages and requires more
standardization to gain wider popularity. Through this survey, we present a
comprehensive overview of PINNs approaches exploring various aspects related to
their architecture, variants, areas of application, real-world use cases,
challenges, and so on. Even though existing surveys can be identified, they
fail to provide a comprehensive view as they primarily focus on either
different application scenarios or limit their study to a superficial level.
This survey attempts to bridge the gap in the existing literature by presenting
a detailed analysis of all these factors combined with recent advancements and
state-of-the-art research in PINNs. Additionally, we discuss prevalent
challenges in PINNs implementation and present some of the future research
directions as well. The overall contributions of the survey can be summarised
into three sections: A detailed overview of PINNs architecture and variants, a
performance analysis of PINNs on different equations and application domains
highlighting their features. Finally, we present a detailed discussion of
current issues and future research directions.

AI.tldr: This paper conducts a comprehensive survey on PINNs, including their architecture, application domains, challenges and future directions.
AI.motivation: The motivation of this paper is to provide a more standardized and comprehensive overview of PINNs approaches, addressing the limitations in existing surveys which either focus on different application scenarios or remain at a superficial level.
AI.method: Through this survey, the authors explore various aspects related to PINNs' architecture, variants, areas of application, real-world use cases, and challenges. They also analyze the performance of PINNs on different equations and application domains.
AI.result: The results include a detailed overview of PINNs architecture and variants, a performance analysis across different domains, and a discussion of current issues and future research directions.
AI.conclusion: This survey successfully bridges the gap in the existing literature by presenting a detailed analysis of all factors related to PINNs combined with recent advancements and state-of-the-art research.

title: $K^2$VAE: A Koopman-Kalman Enhanced Variational AutoEncoder for Probabilistic Time Series Forecasting
summary:
Probabilistic Time Series Forecasting (PTSF) plays a crucial role in
decision-making across various fields, including economics, energy, and
transportation. Most existing methods excell at short-term forecasting, while
overlooking the hurdles of Long-term Probabilistic Time Series Forecasting
(LPTSF). As the forecast horizon extends, the inherent nonlinear dynamics have
a significant adverse effect on prediction accuracy, and make generative models
inefficient by increasing the cost of each iteration. To overcome these
limitations, we introduce $K^2$VAE, an efficient VAE-based generative model
that leverages a KoopmanNet to transform nonlinear time series into a linear
dynamical system, and devises a KalmanNet to refine predictions and model
uncertainty in such linear system, which reduces error accumulation in
long-term forecasting. Extensive experiments demonstrate that $K^2$VAE
outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both short- and long-term PTSF,
providing a more efficient and accurate solution.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes $K^2$VAE, a VAE-based generative model using KoopmanNet and KalmanNet for efficient long-term probabilistic time series forecasting.
AI.motivation: Existing methods for probabilistic time series forecasting are proficient in short-term predictions but struggle with long-term forecasts due to nonlinear dynamics and error accumulation.
AI.method: The method introduces $K^2$VAE which uses KoopmanNet to convert nonlinear time series into a linear dynamical system and KalmanNet to refine predictions and model uncertainty within this linear system.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that $K^2$VAE outperforms current state-of-the-art methods in both short- and long-term probabilistic time series forecasting.
AI.conclusion: $K^2$VAE provides an efficient and accurate solution for long-term probabilistic time series forecasting.

title: MIAS-SAM: Medical Image Anomaly Segmentation without thresholding
summary:
This paper presents MIAS-SAM, a novel approach for the segmentation of
anomalous regions in medical images. MIAS-SAM uses a patch-based memory bank to
store relevant image features, which are extracted from normal data using the
SAM encoder. At inference time, the embedding patches extracted from the SAM
encoder are compared with those in the memory bank to obtain the anomaly map.
Finally, MIAS-SAM computes the center of gravity of the anomaly map to prompt
the SAM decoder, obtaining an accurate segmentation from the previously
extracted features. Differently from prior works, MIAS-SAM does not require to
define a threshold value to obtain the segmentation from the anomaly map.
Experimental results conducted on three publicly available datasets, each with
a different imaging modality (Brain MRI, Liver CT, and Retina OCT) show
accurate anomaly segmentation capabilities measured using DICE score. The code
is available at: https://github.com/warpcut/MIAS-SAM

AI.tldr: This paper presents MIAS-SAM, a novel approach for the segmentation of anomalous regions in medical images which uses a patch-based memory bank and SAM encoder to accurately segment anomalies without requiring a threshold value. Experimental results on three datasets show accurate anomaly segmentation capabilities measured using DICE score.
AI.motivation: To develop a new method for the segmentation of anomalous regions in medical images that does not require defining a threshold value from the anomaly map.
AI.method: MIAS-SAM uses a patch-based memory bank to store relevant image features extracted from normal data using the SAM encoder. At inference time, embedding patches extracted from the SAM encoder are compared with those in the memory bank to obtain the anomaly map. The center of gravity of the anomaly map is then computed to prompt the SAM decoder, obtaining an accurate segmentation from the previously extracted features.
AI.result: Experimental results conducted on three publicly available datasets (Brain MRI, Liver CT, and Retina OCT) show accurate anomaly segmentation capabilities measured using DICE score.
AI.conclusion: MIAS-SAM is a novel approach for the segmentation of anomalous regions in medical images that does not require a threshold value to obtain the segmentation from the anomaly map. It shows accurate anomaly segmentation capabilities across different imaging modalities.

title: SCORPIO: Serving the Right Requests at the Right Time for Heterogeneous SLOs in LLM Inference
summary:
Existing Large Language Model (LLM) serving systems prioritize maximum
throughput. They often neglect Service Level Objectives (SLOs) such as Time to
First Token (TTFT) and Time Per Output Token (TPOT), which leads to suboptimal
SLO attainment. This paper introduces SCORPIO, an SLO-oriented LLM serving
system designed to maximize system goodput and SLO attainment for workloads
with heterogeneous SLOs. Our core insight is to exploit SLO heterogeneity for
adaptive scheduling across admission control, queue management, and batch
selection. SCORPIO features a TTFT Guard, which employs least-deadline-first
reordering and rejects unattainable requests, and a TPOT Guard, which utilizes
a VBS-based admission control and a novel credit-based batching mechanism. Both
guards are supported by a predictive module. Evaluations demonstrate that
SCORPIO improves system goodput by up to 14.4X and SLO adherence by up to 46.5%
compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

AI.tldr: SCORPIO is an SLO-oriented LLM serving system that improves system goodput and SLO adherence by employing TTFT Guard and TPOT Guard.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM serving systems focus on maximum throughput but neglect important SLOs like TTFT and TPOT, resulting in suboptimal SLO attainment.
AI.method: SCORPIO exploits SLO heterogeneity for adaptive scheduling across admission control, queue management, and batch selection. It features a TTFT Guard which employs least-deadline-first reordering and rejects unattainable requests, and a TPOT Guard which utilizes a VBS-based admission control and a novel credit-based batching mechanism.
AI.result: Evaluations show SCORPIO improves system goodput by up to 14.4X and SLO adherence by up to 46.5% compared to state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: SCORPIO successfully enhances the performance of LLM serving systems by focusing on SLOs and improving both system goodput and SLO adherence.

title: In Dialogue with Intelligence: Rethinking Large Language Models as Collective Knowledge
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are typically analysed through architectural,
behavioural, or training-data lenses. This article offers a theoretical and
experiential re-framing: LLMs as dynamic instantiations of Collective human
Knowledge (CK), where intelligence is evoked through dialogue rather than
stored statically. Drawing on concepts from neuroscience and AI, and grounded
in sustained interaction with ChatGPT-4, I examine emergent dialogue patterns,
the implications of fine-tuning, and the notion of co-augmentation: mutual
enhancement between human and machine cognition. This perspective offers a new
lens for understanding interaction, representation, and agency in contemporary
AI systems.

AI.tldr: The paper re-frames Large Language Models (LLMs) as dynamic instantiations of Collective human Knowledge (CK), exploring emergent dialogue patterns, fine-tuning implications, and co-augmentation between human and machine cognition.
AI.motivation: To provide a theoretical and experiential re-framing of LLMs as dynamic instantiations of Collective human Knowledge (CK), shifting from the traditional analysis through architectural, behavioural, or training-data lenses.
AI.method: Examine emergent dialogue patterns, the implications of fine-tuning, and the notion of co-augmentation by drawing on concepts from neuroscience and AI, and interacting with ChatGPT-4.
AI.result: This perspective offers a new lens for understanding interaction, representation, and agency in contemporary AI systems.
AI.conclusion: LLMs can be viewed as evoking intelligence through dialogue rather than storing knowledge statically, leading to mutual enhancement between human and machine cognition.

title: An Empirical Study of Federated Prompt Learning for Vision Language Model
summary:
The Vision Language Model (VLM) excels in aligning vision and language
representations, and prompt learning has emerged as a key technique for
adapting such models to downstream tasks. However, the application of prompt
learning with VLM in federated learning (\fl{}) scenarios remains
underexplored. This paper systematically investigates the behavioral
differences between language prompt learning (LPT) and vision prompt learning
(VPT) under data heterogeneity challenges, including label skew and domain
shift. We conduct extensive experiments to evaluate the impact of various \fl{}
and prompt configurations, such as client scale, aggregation strategies, and
prompt length, to assess the robustness of Federated Prompt Learning (FPL).
Furthermore, we explore strategies for enhancing prompt learning in complex
scenarios where label skew and domain shift coexist, including leveraging both
prompt types when computational resources allow. Our findings offer practical
insights into optimizing prompt learning in federated settings, contributing to
the broader deployment of VLMs in privacy-preserving environments.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the differences and robustness of language prompt learning (LPT) and vision prompt learning (VPT) in federated learning scenarios with data heterogeneity, providing insights for optimizing prompt learning in privacy-preserving environments.
AI.motivation: To understand how prompt learning with Vision Language Models (VLMs) can be adapted to downstream tasks in federated learning settings, especially under challenges like label skew and domain shift.
AI.method: Systematically investigate the behavioral differences between LPT and VPT under data heterogeneity, evaluate various federated learning and prompt configurations, and explore strategies for enhancing prompt learning when both label skew and domain shift are present.
AI.result: Extensive experiments reveal insights into optimizing prompt learning in federated settings, showing the impact of client scale, aggregation strategies, and prompt length on the robustness of Federated Prompt Learning (FPL).
AI.conclusion: The findings provide practical guidance for improving prompt learning in federated learning environments, facilitating broader deployment of VLMs while preserving privacy.

title: Automated Essay Scoring Incorporating Annotations from Automated Feedback Systems
summary:
This study illustrates how incorporating feedback-oriented annotations into
the scoring pipeline can enhance the accuracy of automated essay scoring (AES).
This approach is demonstrated with the Persuasive Essays for Rating, Selecting,
and Understanding Argumentative and Discourse Elements (PERSUADE) corpus. We
integrate two types of feedback-driven annotations: those that identify
spelling and grammatical errors, and those that highlight argumentative
components. To illustrate how this method could be applied in real-world
scenarios, we employ two LLMs to generate annotations -- a generative language
model used for spell-correction and an encoder-based token classifier trained
to identify and mark argumentative elements. By incorporating annotations into
the scoring process, we demonstrate improvements in performance using
encoder-based large language models fine-tuned as classifiers.

AI.tldr: This study shows how feedback-oriented annotations can improve automated essay scoring accuracy using the PERSUADE corpus and two LLMs.
AI.motivation: To enhance the accuracy of automated essay scoring by incorporating feedback-oriented annotations into the scoring pipeline.
AI.method: Integrating two types of annotations - those identifying spelling and grammatical errors, and those highlighting argumentative components - into the AES process using the PERSUADE corpus. Employing a generative language model for spell-correction and an encoder-based token classifier to identify argumentative elements.
AI.result: Demonstrated improvements in performance when using encoder-based large language models fine-tuned as classifiers with the added annotations.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating feedback-oriented annotations enhances the accuracy of automated essay scoring.

title: Diverse Prototypical Ensembles Improve Robustness to Subpopulation Shift
summary:
The subpopulationtion shift, characterized by a disparity in subpopulation
distributibetween theween the training and target datasets, can significantly
degrade the performance of machine learning models. Current solutions to
subpopulation shift involve modifying empirical risk minimization with
re-weighting strategies to improve generalization. This strategy relies on
assumptions about the number and nature of subpopulations and annotations on
group membership, which are unavailable for many real-world datasets. Instead,
we propose using an ensemble of diverse classifiers to adaptively capture risk
associated with subpopulations. Given a feature extractor network, we replace
its standard linear classification layer with a mixture of prototypical
classifiers, where each member is trained to classify the data while focusing
on different features and samples from other members. In empirical evaluation
on nine real-world datasets, covering diverse domains and kinds of
subpopulation shift, our method of Diverse Prototypical Ensembles (DPEs) often
outperforms the prior state-of-the-art in worst-group accuracy. The code is
available at https://github.com/minhto2802/dpe4subpop

AI.tldr: The paper proposes Diverse Prototypical Ensembles (DPEs) to handle subpopulation shift in machine learning models by using an ensemble of diverse classifiers, which often outperforms prior state-of-the-art methods in worst-group accuracy across nine real-world datasets.
AI.motivation: Subpopulation shift can significantly degrade the performance of machine learning models. Current solutions rely on assumptions about subpopulations and annotations that are not always available.
AI.method: Propose using an ensemble of diverse classifiers by replacing the standard linear classification layer with a mixture of prototypical classifiers, each focusing on different features and samples.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on nine real-world datasets shows that DPEs often outperform prior state-of-the-art methods in worst-group accuracy.
AI.conclusion: DPEs provide a promising approach to handling subpopulation shift without relying on specific assumptions or annotations.

title: Bayesian Neural Scaling Laws Extrapolation with Prior-Fitted Networks
summary:
Scaling has been a major driver of recent advancements in deep learning.
Numerous empirical studies have found that scaling laws often follow the
power-law and proposed several variants of power-law functions to predict the
scaling behavior at larger scales. However, existing methods mostly rely on
point estimation and do not quantify uncertainty, which is crucial for
real-world applications involving decision-making problems such as determining
the expected performance improvements achievable by investing additional
computational resources. In this work, we explore a Bayesian framework based on
Prior-data Fitted Networks (PFNs) for neural scaling law extrapolation.
Specifically, we design a prior distribution that enables the sampling of
infinitely many synthetic functions resembling real-world neural scaling laws,
allowing our PFN to meta-learn the extrapolation. We validate the effectiveness
of our approach on real-world neural scaling laws, comparing it against both
the existing point estimation methods and Bayesian approaches. Our method
demonstrates superior performance, particularly in data-limited scenarios such
as Bayesian active learning, underscoring its potential for reliable,
uncertainty-aware extrapolation in practical applications.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a Bayesian framework using Prior-data Fitted Networks (PFNs) for neural scaling law extrapolation, which outperforms existing methods especially in data-limited scenarios.
AI.motivation: Current methods for predicting neural scaling behavior rely on point estimation without quantifying uncertainty, making them unsuitable for real-world decision-making.
AI.method: The authors design a prior distribution to sample synthetic functions resembling real-world neural scaling laws and use this within a Bayesian framework based on PFNs to meta-learn the extrapolation.
AI.result: The method shows superior performance compared to existing point estimation and Bayesian approaches, particularly excelling in data-limited situations like Bayesian active learning.
AI.conclusion: This Bayesian approach provides reliable, uncertainty-aware extrapolation of neural scaling laws, offering practical advantages for real-world applications.

title: From Theory to Application: Fine-Tuning Large EEG Model with Real-World Stress Data
summary:
Recent advancements in Large Language Models have inspired the development of
foundation models across various domains. In this study, we evaluate the
efficacy of Large EEG Models (LEMs) by fine-tuning LaBraM, a state-of-the-art
foundation EEG model, on a real-world stress classification dataset collected
in a graduate classroom. Unlike previous studies that primarily evaluate LEMs
using data from controlled clinical settings, our work assesses their
applicability to real-world environments. We train a binary classifier that
distinguishes between normal and elevated stress states using resting-state EEG
data recorded from 18 graduate students during a class session. The
best-performing fine-tuned model achieves a balanced accuracy of 90.47% with a
5-second window, significantly outperforming traditional stress classifiers in
both accuracy and inference efficiency. We further evaluate the robustness of
the fine-tuned LEM under random data shuffling and reduced channel counts.
These results demonstrate the capability of LEMs to effectively process
real-world EEG data and highlight their potential to revolutionize
brain-computer interface applications by shifting the focus from model-centric
to data-centric design.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the potential of Large EEG Models (LEMs) in real-world stress classification by fine-tuning LaBraM, achieving high accuracy and efficiency.
AI.motivation: To assess the applicability of Large EEG Models (LEMs) in real-world environments beyond controlled clinical settings.
AI.method: Fine-tuned LaBraM, a state-of-the-art foundation EEG model, on a real-world stress classification dataset collected from graduate students in a classroom setting. A binary classifier was trained to distinguish between normal and elevated stress states using resting-state EEG data.
AI.result: The best-performing fine-tuned model achieved a balanced accuracy of 90.47% with a 5-second window, outperforming traditional classifiers in both accuracy and inference efficiency. The model also showed robustness under random data shuffling and reduced channel counts.
AI.conclusion: LEMs can effectively process real-world EEG data, highlighting their potential to revolutionize brain-computer interface applications through a data-centric design approach.

title: First Steps Towards Overhearing LLM Agents: A Case Study With Dungeons & Dragons Gameplay
comment: 8 pages, 5 figures. In submission at EMNLP 2025
summary:
Much work has been done on conversational LLM agents which directly assist
human users with tasks. We present an alternative paradigm for interacting with
LLM agents, which we call "overhearing agents". These overhearing agents do not
actively participate in conversation -- instead, they "listen in" on
human-to-human conversations and perform background tasks or provide
suggestions to assist the user. In this work, we explore the overhearing agents
paradigm through the lens of Dungeons & Dragons gameplay. We present an
in-depth study using large multimodal audio-language models as overhearing
agents to assist a Dungeon Master. We perform a human evaluation to examine the
helpfulness of such agents and find that some large audio-language models have
the emergent ability to perform overhearing agent tasks using implicit audio
cues. Finally, we release Python libraries and our project code to support
further research into the overhearing agents paradigm at
https://github.com/zhudotexe/overhearing_agents.

AI.tldr: 研究人员探索了一种名为'overhearing agents'的新范式，这些代理通过聆听人类对话来执行背景任务或提供建议。他们以Dungeons & Dragons游戏为背景，研究了大型多模式音频-语言模型如何帮助地下城主，并发现了一些模型利用隐含音频线索执行任务的能力。
AI.motivation: 当前关于对话型LLM代理的研究大多集中在直接协助人类用户完成任务，而本研究旨在探索一种新的交互方式——'overhearing agents'，即不主动参与对话，而是通过聆听人类之间的对话来提供辅助。
AI.method: 研究使用大型多模式音频-语言模型作为'overhearing agents'，在Dungeons & Dragons游戏中协助地下城主。通过人类评估来检测这些代理的帮助性，并分析模型是否具备利用隐含音频线索执行任务的能力。
AI.result: 研究发现，一些大型音频-语言模型确实具有利用隐含音频线索执行'overhearing agent'任务的新兴能力。
AI.conclusion: 本研究表明，'overhearing agents'是一种可行且有潜力的LLM应用新范式，同时研究人员发布了Python库和项目代码以支持进一步研究。

title: ProDiff: Prototype-Guided Diffusion for Minimal Information Trajectory Imputation
summary:
Trajectory data is crucial for various applications but often suffers from
incompleteness due to device limitations and diverse collection scenarios.
Existing imputation methods rely on sparse trajectory or travel information,
such as velocity, to infer missing points. However, these approaches assume
that sparse trajectories retain essential behavioral patterns, which place
significant demands on data acquisition and overlook the potential of
large-scale human trajectory embeddings. To address this, we propose ProDiff, a
trajectory imputation framework that uses only two endpoints as minimal
information. It integrates prototype learning to embed human movement patterns
and a denoising diffusion probabilistic model for robust spatiotemporal
reconstruction. Joint training with a tailored loss function ensures effective
imputation. ProDiff outperforms state-of-the-art methods, improving accuracy by
6.28\% on FourSquare and 2.52\% on WuXi. Further analysis shows a 0.927
correlation between generated and real trajectories, demonstrating the
effectiveness of our approach.

AI.tldr: 提出ProDiff框架，仅使用两个端点作为最小信息进行轨迹补全，结合原型学习和去噪扩散概率模型，提升轨迹补全精度。
AI.motivation: 轨迹数据在多种应用中至关重要，但常因设备限制和不同采集场景而存在不完整性。现有的补全方法依赖稀疏轨迹或旅行信息，假设这些稀轨迹保留了基本的行为模式，这给数据获取带来了很大压力，并忽略了大规模人类轨迹嵌入的潜力。
AI.method: 提出ProDiff，一个轨迹补全框架，仅使用两个端点作为最小信息。该框架整合了原型学习以嵌入人类运动模式，并采用去噪扩散概率模型进行鲁棒时空重建。通过定制的损失函数进行联合训练以确保有效的补全。
AI.result: ProDiff在FourSquare上准确率提高了6.28%，在WuXi上提高了2.52%。进一步分析显示生成轨迹与真实轨迹之间的相关性为0.927，证明了该方法的有效性。
AI.conclusion: ProDiff框架在轨迹补全任务中表现出色，超越现有最先进方法，证明了其在利用少量信息进行有效轨迹补全的能力。

title: A Large Language Model-Enabled Control Architecture for Dynamic Resource Capability Exploration in Multi-Agent Manufacturing Systems
summary:
Manufacturing environments are becoming more complex and unpredictable due to
factors such as demand variations and shorter product lifespans. This
complexity requires real-time decision-making and adaptation to disruptions.
Traditional control approaches highlight the need for advanced control
strategies capable of overcoming unforeseen challenges, as they demonstrate
limitations in responsiveness within dynamic industrial settings. Multi-agent
systems address these challenges through decentralization of decision-making,
enabling systems to respond dynamically to operational changes. However,
current multi-agent systems encounter challenges related to real-time
adaptation, context-aware decision-making, and the dynamic exploration of
resource capabilities. Large language models provide the possibility to
overcome these limitations through context-aware decision-making capabilities.
This paper introduces a large language model-enabled control architecture for
multi-agent manufacturing systems to dynamically explore resource capabilities
in response to real-time disruptions. A simulation-based case study
demonstrates that the proposed architecture improves system resilience and
flexibility. The case study findings show improved throughput and efficient
resource utilization compared to existing approaches.

AI.tldr: In this paper, the authors address the challenges faced by traditional control approaches in manufacturing environments due to increasing complexity and unpredictability. They propose a large language model-enabled control architecture for multi-agent manufacturing systems that enhances real-time adaptation and context-aware decision-making, leading to improved system resilience and flexibility.
AI.motivation: Manufacturing environments are becoming more complex and unpredictable, which requires real-time decision-making and adaptation to disruptions. Traditional control approaches show limitations in responsiveness within dynamic industrial settings.
AI.method: The authors introduce a large language model-enabled control architecture for multi-agent manufacturing systems. This architecture aims to dynamically explore resource capabilities in response to real-time disruptions.
AI.result: A simulation-based case study demonstrates that the proposed architecture improves system resilience and flexibility. The findings indicate improved throughput and efficient resource utilization compared to existing approaches.
AI.conclusion: The large language model-enabled control architecture for multi-agent manufacturing systems successfully addresses the challenges related to real-time adaptation, context-aware decision-making, and dynamic exploration of resource capabilities.

title: DenoiseRotator: Enhance Pruning Robustness for LLMs via Importance Concentration
summary:
Pruning is a widely used technique to compress large language models (LLMs)
by removing unimportant weights, but it often suffers from significant
performance degradation - especially under semi-structured sparsity
constraints. Existing pruning methods primarily focus on estimating the
importance of individual weights, which limits their ability to preserve
critical capabilities of the model. In this work, we propose a new perspective:
rather than merely selecting which weights to prune, we first redistribute
parameter importance to make the model inherently more amenable to pruning. By
minimizing the information entropy of normalized importance scores, our
approach concentrates importance onto a smaller subset of weights, thereby
enhancing pruning robustness. We instantiate this idea through DenoiseRotator,
which applies learnable orthogonal transformations to the model's weight
matrices. Our method is model-agnostic and can be seamlessly integrated with
existing pruning techniques such as Magnitude, SparseGPT, and Wanda. Evaluated
on LLaMA3, Qwen2.5, and Mistral models under 50% unstructured and 2:4
semi-structured sparsity, DenoiseRotator consistently improves perplexity and
zero-shot accuracy. For instance, on LLaMA3-70B pruned with SparseGPT at 2:4
semi-structured sparsity, DenoiseRotator reduces the perplexity gap to the
dense model by 58%, narrowing the degradation from 8.1 to 3.4 points. Codes are
available at https://github.com/Axel-gu/DenoiseRotator.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces DenoiseRotator, a method that redistributes parameter importance in large language models (LLMs) to enhance pruning robustness. It applies learnable orthogonal transformations to weight matrices and complements existing pruning techniques. Evaluated on LLaMA3, Qwen2.5, and Mistral models, it consistently improves perplexity and zero-shot accuracy.
AI.motivation: Pruning large language models often leads to significant performance degradation, especially under semi-structured sparsity constraints. Current methods focus on estimating the importance of individual weights rather than making the model inherently more amenable to pruning.
AI.method: DenoiseRotator applies learnable orthogonal transformations to the model's weight matrices. By minimizing the information entropy of normalized importance scores, it concentrates importance onto a smaller subset of weights, thereby enhancing pruning robustness.
AI.result: DenoiseRotator consistently improves perplexity and zero-shot accuracy on LLaMA3, Qwen2.5, and Mistral models under 50% unstructured and 2:4 semi-structured sparsity. For example, on LLaMA3-70B pruned with SparseGPT at 2:4 semi-structured sparsity, it reduces the perplexity gap to the dense model by 58%.
AI.conclusion: DenoiseRotator is a model-agnostic approach that can be seamlessly integrated with existing pruning techniques to improve the performance of pruned large language models.

title: IMTS is Worth Time $\times$ Channel Patches: Visual Masked Autoencoders for Irregular Multivariate Time Series Prediction
summary:
Irregular Multivariate Time Series (IMTS) forecasting is challenging due to
the unaligned nature of multi-channel signals and the prevalence of extensive
missing data. Existing methods struggle to capture reliable temporal patterns
from such data due to significant missing values. While pre-trained foundation
models show potential for addressing these challenges, they are typically
designed for Regularly Sampled Time Series (RTS). Motivated by the visual Mask
AutoEncoder's (MAE) powerful capability for modeling sparse multi-channel
information and its success in RTS forecasting, we propose VIMTS, a framework
adapting Visual MAE for IMTS forecasting. To mitigate the effect of missing
values, VIMTS first processes IMTS along the timeline into feature patches at
equal intervals. These patches are then complemented using learned
cross-channel dependencies. Then it leverages visual MAE's capability in
handling sparse multichannel data for patch reconstruction, followed by a
coarse-to-fine technique to generate precise predictions from focused contexts.
In addition, we integrate self-supervised learning for improved IMTS modeling
by adapting the visual MAE to IMTS data. Extensive experiments demonstrate
VIMTS's superior performance and few-shot capability, advancing the application
of visual foundation models in more general time series tasks. Our code is
available at https://github.com/WHU-HZY/VIMTS.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes VIMTS, a framework adapting Visual Mask AutoEncoder (MAE) for Irregular Multivariate Time Series (IMTS) forecasting. It processes IMTS data into feature patches, uses learned cross-channel dependencies, leverages visual MAE for patch reconstruction and integrates self-supervised learning. Experiments show superior performance and few-shot capability.
AI.motivation: Irregular Multivariate Time Series (IMTS) forecasting is challenging due to unaligned multi-channel signals and extensive missing data. Existing methods struggle with such data, especially when there are significant missing values. The success of pre-trained foundation models in other domains motivates the exploration of similar techniques for IMTS forecasting.
AI.method: VIMTS first processes IMTS along the timeline into feature patches at equal intervals, then complements these patches using learned cross-channel dependencies. It leverages the visual Mask AutoEncoder's (MAE) ability to handle sparse multichannel data for patch reconstruction and applies a coarse-to-fine technique to generate precise predictions. Self-supervised learning is integrated to improve IMTS modeling by adapting visual MAE to IMTS data.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that VIMTS shows superior performance compared to existing methods in IMTS forecasting tasks. It also exhibits strong few-shot learning capabilities, advancing the application of visual foundation models in more general time series tasks.
AI.conclusion: VIMTS effectively addresses the challenges posed by IMTS forecasting through its innovative adaptation of visual Mask AutoEncoder technology. The framework demonstrates superior performance and strong few-shot learning abilities, contributing significantly to the broader application of visual foundation models in time series analysis.

title: CDR-Agent: Intelligent Selection and Execution of Clinical Decision Rules Using Large Language Model Agents
summary:
Clinical decision-making is inherently complex and fast-paced, particularly
in emergency departments (EDs) where critical, rapid and high-stakes decisions
are made. Clinical Decision Rules (CDRs) are standardized evidence-based tools
that combine signs, symptoms, and clinical variables into decision trees to
make consistent and accurate diagnoses. CDR usage is often hindered by the
clinician's cognitive load, limiting their ability to quickly recall and apply
the appropriate rules. We introduce CDR-Agent, a novel LLM-based system
designed to enhance ED decision-making by autonomously identifying and applying
the most appropriate CDRs based on unstructured clinical notes. To validate
CDR-Agent, we curated two novel ED datasets: synthetic and CDR-Bench, although
CDR-Agent is applicable to non ED clinics. CDR-Agent achieves a 56.3\%
(synthetic) and 8.7\% (CDR-Bench) accuracy gain relative to the standalone LLM
baseline in CDR selection. Moreover, CDR-Agent significantly reduces
computational overhead. Using these datasets, we demonstrated that CDR-Agent
not only selects relevant CDRs efficiently, but makes cautious yet effective
imaging decisions by minimizing unnecessary interventions while successfully
identifying most positively diagnosed cases, outperforming traditional LLM
prompting approaches. Code for our work can be found at:
https://github.com/zhenxianglance/medagent-cdr-agent

AI.tldr: An LLM-based system named CDR-Agent is developed to assist clinical decision-making in emergency departments by identifying and applying appropriate Clinical Decision Rules (CDRs). It improves accuracy in CDR selection, reduces computational overhead, and outperforms traditional LLM prompting approaches.
AI.motivation: Clinical decision-making, especially in emergency departments, is complex and fast-paced. The use of Clinical Decision Rules (CDRs) can improve decision-making consistency and accuracy, but their application is often limited by the clinician's cognitive load.
AI.method: The researchers developed CDR-Agent, a novel LLM-based system that autonomously identifies and applies the most appropriate CDRs based on unstructured clinical notes. They curated two datasets, synthetic and CDR-Bench, to validate CDR-Agent's performance.
AI.result: CDR-Agent achieves a 56.3% (synthetic) and 8.7% (CDR-Bench) accuracy gain relative to the standalone LLM baseline in CDR selection. It significantly reduces computational overhead and makes cautious yet effective imaging decisions.
AI.conclusion: CDR-Agent not only selects relevant CDRs efficiently, but also minimizes unnecessary interventions while successfully identifying most positively diagnosed cases, thus outperforming traditional LLM prompting approaches.

title: A Tool for Generating Exceptional Behavior Tests With Large Language Models
summary:
Exceptional behavior tests (EBTs) are crucial in software development for
verifying that code correctly handles unwanted events and throws appropriate
exceptions. However, prior research has shown that developers often prioritize
testing "happy paths", e.g., paths without unwanted events over exceptional
scenarios. We present exLong, a framework that automatically generates EBTs to
address this gap. exLong leverages a large language model (LLM) fine-tuned from
CodeLlama and incorporates reasoning about exception-throwing traces,
conditional expressions that guard throw statements, and non-exceptional
behavior tests that execute similar traces. Our demonstration video illustrates
how exLong can effectively assist developers in creating comprehensive EBTs for
their project (available at https://youtu.be/Jro8kMgplZk).

AI.tldr: exLong is a framework that uses a fine-tuned LLM to automatically generate exceptional behavior tests (EBTs) for software development, addressing the gap of under-tested exceptional scenarios.
AI.motivation: Developers often prioritize testing 'happy paths' rather than exceptional scenarios, leading to a need for better tools to generate EBTs.
AI.method: exLong leverages a large language model fine-tuned from CodeLlama and incorporates reasoning about exception-throwing traces, conditional expressions guarding throw statements, and non-exceptional behavior tests executing similar traces.
AI.result: exLong can effectively assist developers in creating comprehensive EBTs for their projects, as shown in a demonstration video.
AI.conclusion: exLong presents a solution to the under-testing of exceptional scenarios by automating the generation of EBTs.

title: DINGO: Constrained Inference for Diffusion LLMs
comment:
DINGO an algorithm to provably apply constraints to diffusion LLM
  generations
summary:
Diffusion LLMs have emerged as a promising alternative to conventional
autoregressive LLMs, offering significant potential for improved runtime
efficiency. However, existing diffusion models lack the ability to provably
enforce user-specified formal constraints, such as regular expressions, which
makes them unreliable for tasks that require structured outputs, such as
fixed-schema JSON generation. Unlike autoregressive models that generate tokens
sequentially, diffusion LLMs predict a block of tokens in parallel. This
parallelism makes traditional constrained decoding algorithms, which are
designed for sequential token prediction, ineffective at preserving the true
output distribution. To address this limitation, we propose DINGO, a dynamic
programming-based constrained decoding strategy that is both efficient and
provably distribution-preserving. DINGO enables sampling of output strings with
the highest probability under the model's predicted distribution, while
strictly satisfying any user-specified regular expression. On standard symbolic
math and JSON generation benchmarks, DINGO achieves up to a 68 percentage point
improvement over unconstrained inference

AI.tldr: Diffusion LLMs show promise for runtime efficiency but struggle with structured outputs. The paper proposes DINGO, a dynamic programming-based decoding strategy that ensures distribution preservation and satisfies formal constraints, achieving significant improvements on benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To make diffusion LLMs reliable for tasks requiring structured outputs by enforcing user-specified formal constraints.
AI.method: Propose DINGO, an efficient and provably distribution-preserving constrained decoding strategy based on dynamic programming.
AI.result: DINGO achieves up to a 68 percentage point improvement over unconstrained inference on symbolic math and JSON generation benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: DINGO addresses the limitation of diffusion LLMs in handling structured outputs by ensuring constraint satisfaction and maintaining output distribution integrity.

title: Composite Flow Matching for Reinforcement Learning with Shifted-Dynamics Data
summary:
Incorporating pre-collected offline data from a source environment can
significantly improve the sample efficiency of reinforcement learning (RL), but
this benefit is often challenged by discrepancies between the transition
dynamics of the source and target environments. Existing methods typically
address this issue by penalizing or filtering out source transitions in high
dynamics-gap regions. However, their estimation of the dynamics gap often
relies on KL divergence or mutual information, which can be ill-defined when
the source and target dynamics have disjoint support. To overcome these
limitations, we propose CompFlow, a method grounded in the theoretical
connection between flow matching and optimal transport. Specifically, we model
the target dynamics as a conditional flow built upon the output distribution of
the source-domain flow, rather than learning it directly from a Gaussian prior.
This composite structure offers two key advantages: (1) improved generalization
for learning target dynamics, and (2) a principled estimation of the dynamics
gap via the Wasserstein distance between source and target transitions.
Leveraging our principled estimation of the dynamics gap, we further introduce
an optimistic active data collection strategy that prioritizes exploration in
regions of high dynamics gap, and theoretically prove that it reduces the
performance disparity with the optimal policy. Empirically, CompFlow
outperforms strong baselines across several RL benchmarks with shifted
dynamics.

AI.tldr: CompFlow是一种基于流动匹配和最优传输理论的方法，通过建模目标动态作为源域流动输出分布上的条件流，提供改进的目标动态学习泛化能力和对动态差距的合理估计。此外，结合乐观主动数据收集策略，CompFlow在多个RL基准上表现出色。
AI.motivation: 现有的处理源和目标环境动态差异的方法通常通过惩罚或过滤掉高动态差距区域的源转换来解决此问题，但其动态差距估计可能因源和目标动态具有分离支持而未明确定义。因此需要一种新方法以克服这些限制。
AI.method: 提出了一种名为CompFlow的方法，该方法基于流动匹配和最优传输的理论联系。具体而言，将目标动态建模为基于源域流动输出分布的条件流，而不是直接从高斯先验中学习。这种方法提供了两个关键优势：1）改进目标动态学习的泛化能力；2）通过对源和目标转换之间的Wasserstein距离进行合理估计动态差距。进一步引入了一种乐观主动数据收集策略，优先探索高动态差距区域，并从理论上证明它减少了与最优策略的性能差异。
AI.result: CompFlow在几个具有动态偏移的强化学习基准上超越了强大的基线方法。
AI.conclusion: CompFlow通过改进目标动态学习的泛化能力和合理估计动态差距，结合乐观主动数据收集策略，在实践中表现优异并理论上减少与最优策略的性能差异。

title: Loss-Guided Model Sharing and Local Learning Correction in Decentralized Federated Learning for Crop Disease Classification
summary:
Crop disease detection and classification is a critical challenge in
agriculture, with major implications for productivity, food security, and
environmental sustainability. While deep learning models such as CNN and ViT
have shown excellent performance in classifying plant diseases from images,
their large-scale deployment is often limited by data privacy concerns.
Federated Learning (FL) addresses this issue, but centralized FL remains
vulnerable to single-point failures and scalability limits. In this paper, we
introduce a novel Decentralized Federated Learning (DFL) framework that uses
validation loss (Loss_val) both to guide model sharing between peers and to
correct local training via an adaptive loss function controlled by weighting
parameter. We conduct extensive experiments using PlantVillage datasets with
three deep learning architectures (ResNet50, VGG16, and ViT_B16), analyzing the
impact of weighting parameter, the number of shared models, the number of
clients, and the use of Loss_val versus Loss_train of other clients. Results
demonstrate that our DFL approach not only improves accuracy and convergence
speed, but also ensures better generalization and robustness across
heterogeneous data environments making it particularly well-suited for
privacy-preserving agricultural applications.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a Decentralized Federated Learning (DFL) framework for crop disease detection using validation loss to guide model sharing and correct local training.
AI.motivation: Crop disease detection is crucial in agriculture, but data privacy concerns limit the deployment of deep learning models. Federated Learning addresses privacy issues, yet centralized FL has vulnerabilities.
AI.method: A novel DFL framework is introduced which uses validation loss to guide model sharing between peers and corrects local training via an adaptive loss function controlled by a weighting parameter.
AI.result: Experiments with PlantVillage datasets and three deep learning architectures show that the DFL approach improves accuracy, convergence speed, generalization, and robustness across heterogeneous data environments.
AI.conclusion: The DFL framework is well-suited for privacy-preserving agricultural applications, enhancing both performance and data security.

title: What Has Been Lost with Synthetic Evaluation?
comment: 9 pages main, 5 pages reference, 24 pages appendix
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used for data generation.
However, creating evaluation benchmarks raises the bar for this emerging
paradigm. Benchmarks must target specific phenomena, penalize exploiting
shortcuts, and be challenging. Through two case studies, we investigate whether
LLMs can meet these demands by generating reasoning over-text benchmarks and
comparing them to those created through careful crowdsourcing. Specifically, we
evaluate both the validity and difficulty of LLM-generated versions of two
high-quality reading comprehension datasets: CondaQA, which evaluates reasoning
about negation, and DROP, which targets reasoning about quantities. We find
that prompting LLMs can produce variants of these datasets that are often valid
according to the annotation guidelines, at a fraction of the cost of the
original crowdsourcing effort. However, we show that they are less challenging
for LLMs than their human-authored counterparts. This finding sheds light on
what may have been lost by generating evaluation data with LLMs, and calls for
critically reassessing the immediate use of this increasingly prevalent
approach to benchmark creation.

AI.tldr: 大型语言模型（LLMs）可用于生成数据，但创建评估基准仍具挑战。通过两个案例研究，我们探讨了LLMs是否能生成有效的推理文本基准，并与精心设计的人工众包基准进行了比较。结果表明，LLMs生成的基准在成本上更具优势，但在难度和挑战性方面不及人工生成的版本。这提示我们需要重新评估使用LLMs生成评估数据的即时性。
AI.motivation: 尽管大型语言模型被越来越多地用于数据生成，但创建合适的评估基准仍然是一个难题。需要针对特定现象、避免利用捷径并且具有挑战性的基准。因此，研究者希望通过案例研究来探索LLMs生成的基准是否能够满足这些需求。
AI.method: 研究者选择了两个高质量的阅读理解数据集CondaQA和DROP作为案例，分别评估关于否定和数量的推理能力。通过提示LLMs生成这些数据集的变体，并根据标注指南评估其有效性和难度，最后将其与人工众包生成的数据集进行比较。
AI.result: LLMs生成的数据集变体在有效性上符合标注指南，且成本远低于原始的人工众包工作。然而，它们对LLMs本身的挑战性较小，相较于人工生成的版本显得较为简单。
AI.conclusion: 虽然LLMs可以生成有效的评估数据，但其生成的基准可能缺乏足够的挑战性，提示我们在实际应用中需要谨慎对待这种日益普遍的基准创建方法。

title: Multi-Modal Learning with Bayesian-Oriented Gradient Calibration
summary:
Multi-Modal Learning (MML) integrates information from diverse modalities to
improve predictive accuracy. However, existing methods mainly aggregate
gradients with fixed weights and treat all dimensions equally, overlooking the
intrinsic gradient uncertainty of each modality. This may lead to (i) excessive
updates in sensitive dimensions, degrading performance, and (ii) insufficient
updates in less sensitive dimensions, hindering learning. To address this
issue, we propose BOGC-MML, a Bayesian-Oriented Gradient Calibration method for
MML to explicitly model the gradient uncertainty and guide the model
optimization towards the optimal direction. Specifically, we first model each
modality's gradient as a random variable and derive its probability
distribution, capturing the full uncertainty in the gradient space. Then, we
propose an effective method that converts the precision (inverse variance) of
each gradient distribution into a scalar evidence. This evidence quantifies the
confidence of each modality in every gradient dimension. Using these evidences,
we explicitly quantify per-dimension uncertainties and fuse them via a reduced
Dempster-Shafer rule. The resulting uncertainty-weighted aggregation produces a
calibrated update direction that balances sensitivity and conservatism across
dimensions. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate
the effectiveness and advantages of the proposed method.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes BOGC-MML, a Bayesian-Oriented Gradient Calibration method for Multi-Modal Learning (MML), which models gradient uncertainty to improve model optimization and predictive accuracy.
AI.motivation: Existing MML methods aggregate gradients with fixed weights and treat all dimensions equally, ignoring the intrinsic gradient uncertainty of each modality. This can degrade performance in sensitive dimensions and hinder learning in less sensitive ones.
AI.method: BOGC-MML models each modality's gradient as a random variable, derives its probability distribution, converts the precision of each gradient distribution into scalar evidence, quantifies per-dimension uncertainties, and fuses them via a reduced Dempster-Shafer rule.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and advantages of BOGC-MML.
AI.conclusion: BOGC-MML addresses the issue of gradient uncertainty in MML by providing a calibrated update direction that balances sensitivity and conservatism across dimensions.

title: Orca: Browsing at Scale Through User-Driven and AI-Facilitated Orchestration Across Malleable Webpages
summary:
Web-based activities are fundamentally distributed across webpages. However,
conventional browsers with stacks of tabs fail to support operating and
synthesizing large volumes of information across pages. While recent AI systems
enable fully automated web browsing and information synthesis, they often
diminish user agency and hinder contextual understanding. Therefore, we explore
how AI could instead augment users' interactions with content across webpages
and mitigate cognitive and manual efforts. Through literature on information
tasks and web browsing challenges, and an iterative design process, we present
a rich set of novel interactions with our prototype web browser, Orca.
Leveraging AI, Orca supports user-driven exploration, operation, organization,
and synthesis of web content at scale. To enable browsing at scale, webpages
are treated as malleable materials that humans and AI can collaboratively
manipulate and compose into a malleable, dynamic, and browser-level workspace.
Our evaluation revealed an increased "appetite" for information foraging,
enhanced user control, and more flexibility in sensemaking across a broader
information landscape on the web.

AI.tldr: Orca is a prototype web browser that uses AI to augment users' interactions with webpages, treating them as malleable materials for collaborative manipulation and composition, enhancing information foraging, user control, and sensemaking flexibility.
AI.motivation: Conventional browsers struggle to handle large volumes of information across pages, and fully automated AI systems can reduce user agency and contextual understanding. There's a need for AI to augment user interaction with web content instead of replacing it.
AI.method: Through literature review on information tasks and web browsing challenges, followed by an iterative design process, the authors developed Orca, a prototype web browser leveraging AI to support user-driven exploration, operation, organization, and synthesis of web content at scale.
AI.result: Evaluation showed increased appetite for information foraging, enhanced user control, and more flexibility in making sense of a broader information landscape on the web.
AI.conclusion: AI-augmented interactions with webpages can significantly improve user experience, offering greater control and flexibility in managing large-scale information across webpages.

title: Gradient Boosting Decision Tree with LSTM for Investment Prediction
comment: This paper have been accepted by IEEE confulence
summary:
This paper proposes a hybrid framework combining LSTM (Long Short-Term
Memory) networks with LightGBM and CatBoost for stock price prediction. The
framework processes time-series financial data and evaluates performance using
seven models: Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), Convolutional Neural Networks
(CNNs), Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM), vanilla LSTM, XGBoost, LightGBM, and
standard Neural Networks (NNs). Key metrics, including MAE, R-squared, MSE, and
RMSE, are used to establish benchmarks across different time scales.
  Building on these benchmarks, we develop an ensemble model that combines the
strengths of sequential and tree-based approaches. Experimental results show
that the proposed framework improves accuracy by 10 to 15 percent compared to
individual models and reduces error during market changes. This study
highlights the potential of ensemble methods for financial forecasting and
provides a flexible design for integrating new machine learning techniques.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a hybrid framework that combines LSTM networks with LightGBM and CatBoost for stock price prediction, improving accuracy by 10-15% compared to individual models.
AI.motivation: The motivation of this paper is to improve the accuracy of stock price prediction by leveraging the strengths of both sequential (LSTM) and tree-based (LightGBM, CatBoost) machine learning models.
AI.method: The method involves processing time-series financial data using seven different models (ANNs, CNNs, BiLSTM, vanilla LSTM, XGBoost, LightGBM, standard NNs) and then developing an ensemble model that integrates the strengths of sequential and tree-based approaches.
AI.result: Experimental results indicate that the proposed hybrid framework enhances accuracy by 10 to 15 percent in comparison to individual models and effectively reduces error during market changes.
AI.conclusion: This study concludes that ensemble methods have significant potential in financial forecasting and offers a flexible design for incorporating new machine learning techniques.

title: Equivariant Spherical Transformer for Efficient Molecular Modeling
summary:
SE(3)-equivariant Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have significantly advanced
molecular system modeling by employing group representations. However, their
message passing processes, which rely on tensor product-based convolutions, are
limited by insufficient non-linearity and incomplete group representations,
thereby restricting expressiveness. To overcome these limitations, we introduce
the Equivariant Spherical Transformer (EST), a novel framework that leverages a
Transformer structure within the spatial domain of group representations after
Fourier transform. We theoretically and empirically demonstrate that EST can
encompass the function space of tensor products while achieving superior
expressiveness. Furthermore, EST's equivariant inductive bias is guaranteed
through a uniform sampling strategy for the Fourier transform. Our experiments
demonstrate state-of-the-art performance by EST on various molecular
benchmarks, including OC20 and QM9.

AI.tldr: SE(3)-equivariant Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have advanced molecular system modeling, but their expressiveness is restricted. This paper introduces Equivariant Spherical Transformer (EST), which uses a Transformer structure within the spatial domain of group representations after Fourier transform to improve expressiveness.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitations of SE(3)-equivariant GNNs in terms of insufficient non-linearity and incomplete group representations that restrict expressiveness.
AI.method: The Equivariant Spherical Transformer (EST) leverages a Transformer structure within the spatial domain of group representations after Fourier transform. It encompasses the function space of tensor products while achieving superior expressiveness with equivariant inductive bias guaranteed through uniform sampling strategy for the Fourier transform.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate state-of-the-art performance by EST on various molecular benchmarks, including OC20 and QM9.
AI.conclusion: EST theoretically and empirically surpasses existing methods in expressiveness and achieves state-of-the-art performance on molecular benchmarks.

title: MAP: Revisiting Weight Decomposition for Low-Rank Adaptation
summary:
The rapid development of large language models has revolutionized natural
language processing, but their fine-tuning remains computationally expensive,
hindering broad deployment. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) methods,
such as LoRA, have emerged as solutions. Recent work like DoRA attempts to
further decompose weight adaptation into direction and magnitude components.
However, existing formulations often define direction heuristically at the
column level, lacking a principled geometric foundation. In this paper, we
propose MAP, a novel framework that reformulates weight matrices as
