AI.tldr: The paper explores the use of PCA in medical image segmentation to improve model performance across unseen ultrasound datasets. By reducing dimensionality, PCA enhances essential features and reduces noise, leading to better recall and Dice scores when using reconstructed datasets. This method significantly mitigates performance decline in external validation.
AI.motivation: Medical image segmentation models face challenges with external validity, especially in ultrasound imaging where datasets are small and diverse. Current solutions like domain adaptation or GAN-based style transfer have limitations in such scenarios.
AI.method: The authors apply PCA preprocessing to reduce noise and highlight essential features by retaining 90% of dataset variance. They create PCA-reconstructed datasets from six breast tumor ultrasound datasets and train U-Net-based segmentation models on both original and PCA datasets. Models are then tested across out-of-domain datasets for comparison.
AI.result: PCA reconstruction improved recall and Dice scores compared to baseline results, particularly for challenging cases. Statistically significant gains were observed in recall (0.57 ± 0.07 vs. 0.70 ± 0.05, p = 0.0004) and Dice scores (0.50 ± 0.06 vs. 0.58 ± 0.06, p = 0.03). The method reduced recall decline during external validation by 33%.
AI.conclusion: PCA reconstruction can serve as an effective safeguard against declines in segmentation performance due to external validation, offering potential improvements in real-world medical applications.

title: Multilook Coherent Imaging: Theoretical Guarantees and Algorithms
comment:
29 pages, 4 figures, 3 tables. arXiv admin note: substantial text
  overlap with arXiv:2402.15635
summary:
Multilook coherent imaging is a widely used technique in applications such as
digital holography, ultrasound imaging, and synthetic aperture radar. A central
challenge in these systems is the presence of multiplicative noise, commonly
known as speckle, which degrades image quality. Despite the widespread use of
coherent imaging systems, their theoretical foundations remain relatively
underexplored. In this paper, we study both the theoretical and algorithmic
aspects of likelihood-based approaches for multilook coherent imaging,
providing a rigorous framework for analysis and method development. Our
theoretical contributions include establishing the first theoretical upper
bound on the Mean Squared Error (MSE) of the maximum likelihood estimator under
the deep image prior hypothesis. Our results capture the dependence of MSE on
the number of parameters in the deep image prior, the number of looks, the
signal dimension, and the number of measurements per look. On the algorithmic
side, we employ projected gradient descent (PGD) as an efficient method for
computing the maximum likelihood solution. Furthermore, we introduce two key
ideas to enhance the practical performance of PGD. First, we incorporate the
Newton-Schulz algorithm to compute matrix inverses within the PGD iterations,
significantly reducing computational complexity. Second, we develop a bagging
strategy to mitigate projection errors introduced during PGD updates. We
demonstrate that combining these techniques with PGD yields state-of-the-art
performance. Our code is available at
https://github.com/Computational-Imaging-RU/Bagged-DIP-Speckle.

AI.tldr: 本文研究了多视相干成像的最大似然估计方法的理论和算法方面，提出了均方误差的理论上限，并通过改进投影梯度下降法提高了实际性能。
AI.motivation: 尽管多视相干成像技术在数字全息、超声成像和合成孔径雷达等领域广泛应用，但其理论基础尚未得到充分探索，尤其是如何处理降低图像质量的乘性噪声（即斑点噪声）。
AI.method: 作者首先建立了最大似然估计器在深度图像先验假设下的均方误差的理论上限，分析了误差与参数数量、视图数量、信号维度和每视图测量次数的关系。在算法方面，采用了投影梯度下降法计算最大似然解，并引入了Newton-Schulz算法以降低计算复杂度，同时开发了一种装袋策略来减少投影误差。
AI.result: 结合这些技术的投影梯度下降法达到了最先进的性能水平。
AI.conclusion: 本文为多视相干成像提供了严格的理论和算法框架，不仅明确了最大似然估计器的误差界限，还通过改进的投影梯度下降法提升了实际应用中的性能。

title: Few-Shot Speech Deepfake Detection Adaptation with Gaussian Processes
summary:
Recent advancements in Text-to-Speech (TTS) models, particularly in voice
cloning, have intensified the demand for adaptable and efficient deepfake
detection methods. As TTS systems continue to evolve, detection models must be
able to efficiently adapt to previously unseen generation models with minimal
data. This paper introduces ADD-GP, a few-shot adaptive framework based on a
Gaussian Process (GP) classifier for Audio Deepfake Detection (ADD). We show
how the combination of a powerful deep embedding model with the Gaussian
processes flexibility can achieve strong performance and adaptability.
Additionally, we show this approach can also be used for personalized
detection, with greater robustness to new TTS models and one-shot adaptability.
To support our evaluation, a benchmark dataset is constructed for this task
using new state-of-the-art voice cloning models.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces ADD-GP, a few-shot adaptive framework based on a Gaussian Process (GP) classifier for Audio Deepfake Detection (ADD), which combines a deep embedding model with GP flexibility for strong performance and adaptability, personalized detection, robustness to new TTS models, and one-shot adaptability. A benchmark dataset is also constructed.
AI.motivation: The motivation lies in the increasing demand for adaptable and efficient deepfake detection methods due to advancements in Text-to-Speech models, particularly voice cloning. Detection models need to adapt efficiently to unseen generation models with minimal data.
AI.method: The method involves introducing ADD-GP, a few-shot adaptive framework that uses a Gaussian Process (GP) classifier for Audio Deepfake Detection. It combines a deep embedding model with the flexibility of Gaussian processes for enhanced performance and adaptability.
AI.result: This approach not only achieves strong performance and adaptability but also supports personalized detection with greater robustness to new TTS models and one-shot adaptability.
AI.conclusion: The conclusion highlights the effectiveness of ADD-GP in Audio Deepfake Detection, its adaptability to new TTS models, and its potential for personalized detection. A benchmark dataset was constructed to support evaluation.

title: Instance-Optimality for Private KL Distribution Estimation
summary:
We study the fundamental problem of estimating an unknown discrete
distribution $p$ over $d$ symbols, given $n$ i.i.d. samples from the
distribution. We are interested in minimizing the KL divergence between the
true distribution and the algorithm's estimate. We first construct minimax
optimal private estimators. Minimax optimality however fails to shed light on
an algorithm's performance on individual (non-worst-case) instances $p$ and
simple minimax-optimal DP estimators can have poor empirical performance on
real distributions. We then study this problem from an instance-optimality
viewpoint, where the algorithm's error on $p$ is compared to the minimum
achievable estimation error over a small local neighborhood of $p$. Under
natural notions of local neighborhood, we propose algorithms that achieve
instance-optimality up to constant factors, with and without a differential
privacy constraint. Our upper bounds rely on (private) variants of the
Good-Turing estimator. Our lower bounds use additive local neighborhoods that
more precisely captures the hardness of distribution estimation in KL
divergence, compared to ones considered in prior works.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the problem of estimating an unknown discrete distribution with a focus on minimizing KL divergence. It constructs minimax optimal private estimators and then examines instance-optimality, proposing algorithms that achieve this optimality with or without differential privacy constraints.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of minimax optimality in evaluating an algorithm's performance on individual (non-worst-case) instances, the study shifts to an instance-optimality viewpoint for more precise estimation error evaluation.
AI.method: The research first constructs minimax optimal private estimators, then proposes algorithms achieving instance-optimality up to constant factors, utilizing (private) variants of the Good-Turing estimator.
AI.result: Algorithms are developed that achieve instance-optimality both with and without differential privacy constraints. Upper and lower bounds for estimation errors are established.
AI.conclusion: The study successfully provides a framework for instance-optimal distribution estimation under KL divergence, offering improved methods over traditional minimax approaches.

title: Are Reasoning Models More Prone to Hallucination?
summary:
Recently evolved large reasoning models (LRMs) show powerful performance in
solving complex tasks with long chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning capability. As
these LRMs are mostly developed by post-training on formal reasoning tasks,
whether they generalize the reasoning capability to help reduce hallucination
in fact-seeking tasks remains unclear and debated. For instance, DeepSeek-R1
reports increased performance on SimpleQA, a fact-seeking benchmark, while
OpenAI-o3 observes even severer hallucination. This discrepancy naturally
raises the following research question: Are reasoning models more prone to
hallucination? This paper addresses the question from three perspectives. (1)
We first conduct a holistic evaluation for the hallucination in LRMs. Our
analysis reveals that LRMs undergo a full post-training pipeline with cold
start supervised fine-tuning (SFT) and verifiable reward RL generally alleviate
their hallucination. In contrast, both distillation alone and RL training
without cold start fine-tuning introduce more nuanced hallucinations. (2) To
explore why different post-training pipelines alters the impact on
hallucination in LRMs, we conduct behavior analysis. We characterize two
critical cognitive behaviors that directly affect the factuality of a LRM: Flaw
Repetition, where the surface-level reasoning attempts repeatedly follow the
same underlying flawed logic, and Think-Answer Mismatch, where the final answer
fails to faithfully match the previous CoT process. (3) Further, we investigate
the mechanism behind the hallucination of LRMs from the perspective of model
uncertainty. We find that increased hallucination of LRMs is usually associated
with the misalignment between model uncertainty and factual accuracy. Our work
provides an initial understanding of the hallucination in LRMs.

AI.tldr: Recent large reasoning models (LRMs) show strong performance in complex tasks but their tendency to hallucinate in fact-seeking tasks is unclear. This paper evaluates LRMs' hallucination, analyzes post-training impacts, identifies critical cognitive behaviors affecting factuality, and investigates the relationship between model uncertainty and factual accuracy.
AI.motivation: To understand if reasoning models are more prone to hallucination and how different post-training methods affect this issue.
AI.method: 1) Holistic evaluation of hallucination in LRMs. 2) Behavior analysis identifying Flaw Repetition and Think-Answer Mismatch. 3) Investigation into the relationship between model uncertainty and factual accuracy.
AI.result: LRMs with full post-training including cold start SFT and verifiable reward RL reduce hallucination, while distillation alone or RL without cold start fine-tuning increases nuanced hallucinations. Two cognitive behaviors significantly impact factuality. Increased hallucination correlates with misalignment between model uncertainty and factual accuracy.
AI.conclusion: This work provides an initial understanding of hallucination in LRMs through evaluation, behavior analysis, and investigation into model uncertainty.

title: Optimization-Free Diffusion Model -- A Perturbation Theory Approach
summary:
Diffusion models have emerged as a powerful framework in generative modeling,
typically relying on optimizing neural networks to estimate the score function
via forward SDE simulations. In this work, we propose an alternative method
that is both optimization-free and forward SDE-free. By expanding the score
function in a sparse set of eigenbasis of the backward Kolmogorov operator
associated with the diffusion process, we reformulate score estimation as the
solution to a linear system, avoiding iterative optimization and time-dependent
sample generation. We analyze the approximation error using perturbation theory
and demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on high-dimensional Boltzmann
distributions and real-world datasets.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an optimization-free and forward SDE-free method for estimating the score function in diffusion models by expanding it in a sparse set of eigenbasis of the backward Kolmogorov operator, reformulating score estimation as solving a linear system.
AI.motivation: Diffusion models typically rely on optimizing neural networks to estimate the score function via forward SDE simulations. This process can be computationally expensive and complex.
AI.method: The authors propose expanding the score function in a sparse set of eigenbasis of the backward Kolmogorov operator associated with the diffusion process, which allows them to reformulate score estimation as the solution to a linear system, thus avoiding iterative optimization and time-dependent sample generation.
AI.result: The approximation error is analyzed using perturbation theory, and the effectiveness of the method is demonstrated on high-dimensional Boltzmann distributions and real-world datasets.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method provides an alternative approach to score estimation in diffusion models that is both optimization-free and forward SDE-free, showing promise for more efficient generative modeling.

title: LoLA: Low-Rank Linear Attention With Sparse Caching
summary:
Transformer-based large language models suffer from quadratic complexity at
inference on long sequences. Linear attention methods are efficient
alternatives, however, they fail to provide an accurate approximation of
softmax attention. By additionally incorporating sliding window attention into
each linear attention head, this gap can be closed for short context-length
tasks. Unfortunately, these approaches cannot recall important information from
long contexts due to "memory collisions". In this paper , we propose LoLA:
Low-rank Linear Attention with sparse caching. LoLA separately stores
additional key-value pairs that would otherwise interfere with past associative
memories. Moreover, LoLA further closes the gap between linear attention models
and transformers by distributing past key-value pairs into three forms of
memory: (i) recent pairs in a local sliding window; (ii) difficult-to-memorize
pairs in a sparse, global cache; and (iii) generic pairs in the recurrent
hidden state of linear attention. As an inference-only strategy, LoLA enables
pass-key retrieval on up to 8K context lengths on needle-in-a-haystack tasks
from RULER. It boosts the accuracy of the base subquadratic model from 0.6% to
97.4% at 4K context lengths, with a 4.6x smaller cache than that of Llama-3.1
8B. LoLA demonstrates strong performance on zero-shot commonsense reasoning
tasks among 1B and 8B parameter subquadratic models. Finally, LoLA is an
extremely lightweight approach: Nearly all of our results can be reproduced on
a single consumer GPU.

AI.tldr: Transformer-based large language models face challenges with quadratic complexity during inference on long sequences. While linear attention methods are more efficient, they do not accurately approximate softmax attention. This paper introduces LoLA (Low-rank Linear Attention with sparse caching), which addresses these issues by separately storing key-value pairs that might interfere with past associative memories. LoLA uses three forms of memory to close the gap between linear attention models and transformers. It significantly improves accuracy in base subquadratic models at 4K context lengths and performs well on zero-shot commonsense reasoning tasks. Additionally, LoLA is a lightweight approach that can be reproduced on a single consumer GPU.
AI.motivation: The motivation behind this research is to address the limitations of transformer-based large language models, specifically their quadratic complexity during inference on long sequences. The authors also aim to improve upon linear attention methods, which, although more efficient, fail to provide an accurate approximation of softmax attention.
AI.method: LoLA employs Low-rank Linear Attention with sparse caching. It stores additional key-value pairs that could otherwise interfere with past associative memories. Furthermore, it distributes past key-value pairs into three types of memory: recent pairs in a local sliding window, difficult-to-memorize pairs in a sparse global cache, and generic pairs in the recurrent hidden state of linear attention.
AI.result: LoLA enables pass-key retrieval on up to 8K context lengths on needle-in-a-haystack tasks from RULER. It boosts the accuracy of the base subquadratic model from 0.6% to 97.4% at 4K context lengths, with a 4.6x smaller cache than Llama-3.1 8B. LoLA demonstrates strong performance on zero-shot commonsense reasoning tasks among 1B and 8B parameter subquadratic models.
AI.conclusion: LoLA proves to be an effective and lightweight solution for improving the efficiency and accuracy of linear attention models when dealing with long context lengths. Its results can be reproduced on a single consumer GPU, making it an accessible approach.

title: Mobi-$π$: Mobilizing Your Robot Learning Policy
summary:
Learned visuomotor policies are capable of performing increasingly complex
manipulation tasks. However, most of these policies are trained on data
collected from limited robot positions and camera viewpoints. This leads to
poor generalization to novel robot positions, which limits the use of these
policies on mobile platforms, especially for precise tasks like pressing
buttons or turning faucets. In this work, we formulate the policy mobilization
problem: find a mobile robot base pose in a novel environment that is in
distribution with respect to a manipulation policy trained on a limited set of
camera viewpoints. Compared to retraining the policy itself to be more robust
to unseen robot base pose initializations, policy mobilization decouples
navigation from manipulation and thus does not require additional
demonstrations. Crucially, this problem formulation complements existing
efforts to improve manipulation policy robustness to novel viewpoints and
remains compatible with them. To study policy mobilization, we introduce the
Mobi-$\pi$ framework, which includes: (1) metrics that quantify the difficulty
of mobilizing a given policy, (2) a suite of simulated mobile manipulation
tasks based on RoboCasa to evaluate policy mobilization, (3) visualization
tools for analysis, and (4) several baseline methods. We also propose a novel
approach that bridges navigation and manipulation by optimizing the robot's
base pose to align with an in-distribution base pose for a learned policy. Our
approach utilizes 3D Gaussian Splatting for novel view synthesis, a score
function to evaluate pose suitability, and sampling-based optimization to
identify optimal robot poses. We show that our approach outperforms baselines
in both simulation and real-world environments, demonstrating its effectiveness
for policy mobilization.

AI.tldr: Learned visuomotor policies struggle with generalization to novel robot positions. This paper introduces policy mobilization, a method that finds suitable mobile robot base poses for manipulation tasks without retraining the policy. The Mobi-$\pi$ framework is introduced for studying this problem, and a novel approach outperforms baselines in aligning the robot's base pose with an in-distribution pose.
AI.motivation: Current learned visuomotor policies have poor generalization to new robot positions due to limited training data from fixed viewpoints, restricting their use on mobile platforms for precise tasks.
AI.method: The policy mobilization problem is formulated to find a mobile robot base pose that matches the distribution of a manipulation policy trained on limited viewpoints. The Mobi-$\pi$ framework includes metrics, simulated tasks, visualization tools, and baseline methods. A novel approach optimizes the robot's base pose using 3D Gaussian Splatting, a score function, and sampling-based optimization.
AI.result: The proposed approach surpasses baselines in both simulation and real-world environments, proving its effectiveness for policy mobilization.
AI.conclusion: Policy mobilization decouples navigation from manipulation, enhancing the use of learned visuomotor policies on mobile platforms without requiring additional retraining.

title: On the Convergence Analysis of Muon
summary:
The majority of parameters in neural networks are naturally represented as
matrices. However, most commonly used optimizers treat these matrix parameters
as flattened vectors during optimization, potentially overlooking their
inherent structural properties. Recently, an optimizer called Muon has been
proposed, specifically designed to optimize matrix-structured parameters.
Extensive empirical evidence shows that Muon can significantly outperform
traditional optimizers when training neural networks. Nonetheless, the
theoretical understanding of Muon's convergence behavior and the reasons behind
its superior performance remain limited. In this work, we present a
comprehensive convergence rate analysis of Muon and its comparison with
Gradient Descent (GD). We further characterize the conditions under which Muon
can outperform GD. Our theoretical results reveal that Muon can benefit from
the low-rank and approximate blockwise diagonal structure of Hessian matrices
-- phenomena widely observed in practical neural network training. Our
experimental results support and corroborate the theoretical findings.

AI.tldr: 研究了Muon优化器的收敛性，发现其在低秩和近似块对角结构的Hessian矩阵情况下优于梯度下降法，并通过实验验证了这一理论。
AI.motivation: 尽管Muon优化器在神经网络训练中表现出色，但对其收敛行为和优越性能背后的理论理解仍然有限。
AI.method: 对Muon优化器进行了全面的收敛率分析，并与梯度下降法进行比较，同时刻画了Muon优于梯度下降法的条件。
AI.result: 理论结果表明，Muon可以从低秩和近似块对角结构的Hessian矩阵中受益，这种现象在实际神经网络训练中广泛存在。实验结果支持并证实了这些理论发现。
AI.conclusion: Muon优化器在具有低秩和近似块对角结构的Hessian矩阵的情况下表现优于梯度下降法。
